Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech and democratic values.
It creates two classes of citizens, unfairly targeting ordinary citizens with fines and restrictions.
Judging truth is difficult, and authorities can be wrong, as shown in past public health debates.
The bill targets not only false information but also true information deemed misleading.
It favors large digital services and hinders competition from smaller platforms.
Free market competition between platforms can naturally address misinformation.
The extraterritorial application of the bill is problematic and risks alienating Australia globally.
The bill interferes with the implied constitutional freedom of political communication.
Threats and penalties discourage public discourse and resemble authoritarian approaches.
Notable Quotes: The existence of this bill demonstrates a lack of respect for the freedom of speech of Australian citizens.
History has shown that even authorities and expert consensus can sometimes be incorrect.
The bill's interference with the implied constitutional freedom of political communication raises concerns about its impact on democracy.
Such actions resemble an authoritarian approach, reminiscent of the Soviet regime, and are contrary to Australian values of mateship and respect for diverse viewpoints.
